name: C#
description: C# is our language of choice. It's strongly-typed, blends functional and object-oriented programming and works on all the OS we need to support.

name: TypeScript
description: TypeScript is our default choice for running code in the browser. It's strongly-typed and smoothes out the rough bits of JavaScript.

name: Go
description: Go is the natural language to use when extending Kubernetes with operators.

name: Java
description: Redgate purchased Flyway, written in Java. Java is a plausible choice for new products (due to its rich ecosystem), but we default to C#.

name: Bash
description: Bash is our default choice for scripting internal tools. Everyone should be familiar with the Bash toolkit.

name: PowerShell
description: Don't use PowerShell for new projects - prefer Bash.

name: .NET 5
description: .NET 5 is now cross-platform and a great choice for desktop, web and cloud-based applications.

name: .NET Core
description: Don't use .NET Core - we've moved on to .NET 5.

name: ASP.NET Core
description: ASP.NET.

name: React
description: React makes it painless to create interactive UIs.

name: Electron
description: Electron has proved itself for developing web-based desktop products. It's our default choice for new desktop-based applications.

name: WinForms
description: Don't use WinForms for new projects - prefer Electron.

name: WPF
description: Don't use WPF for new projects - prefer Electron.

name: Blazor.Net
description: Blazor is super exciting. It means we might get to leverage our existing C# skills in the browser. It's too early for Redgate to commit to using this in production, so it's in assess so we can keep a good understanding of developments in this area.

name: Visual Studio
description: Visual Studio is our default IDE for developing in C#. We get the Enterprise edition via our MSDN subscription.

name: Rider
description: Many teams use Rider instead of Visual Studio for their development. We have licences for it.

name: VS Code
description: A free lightweight IDE. Our text editor of choice.

name: GitHub
description: All development should use GitHub.

name: TeamCity
description: TeamCity is our default build system.

name: Azure DevOps
description: We believe Azure DevOps might be a fine alternative to TeamCity.

name: GitHub Actions
description: We're keeping an eye on GitHub actions as part of simplifying our build process.

name: Redgate.Build
description: Redgate.Build is our own PowerShell based build scripts. Over time it's become complicated and we wouldn't recommend it for new projects.

name: Terraform
description: Used for automating infrastucture provisioning.

name: Application Insights
description: All applications should use Application Insights as the default developer telemetry platform (incl. feature usage and error reporting).

name: Raygun
description: Deprecated in favour of Application Insights

name: Flyway
description: Our default tool for migrating database schemas.

name: WSL 2
description: Windows Subsystem for Linux should be installed on every development machine

name: SignalR
description: SignalR is our default choice for push-functionality.

name: Hashicorp Vault
description: We recommend Hashicorp Vault for storing secrets.

name: Keepass files in GitHub
description: Use a password manager (or Vault) instead.

name: Docker
description: Docker should be used as the default containerisation technology. Used for building, testing and deployment.

name: gRPC
description: gRPC is a high-performance RPC framework which we may investigate for high-volume data collection (for example, SQL Monitor).

name: Snyk
description: We use Snyk to scan for known vulnerabilities in our products' dependencies.

name: DocFx
description: DocFX is an extensible and scalable static documentation generator. We're experimenting with it for the web version of the progression framework. Could this be a future solution to host our documentation too?

name: Makefiles
description: Should we fall back to using Makefiles as part of a simpler build process? Again, this is part of our desire to simplify our build process.

name: Cake
description: Cake is a free and OSS cross-platform build automation system with a C# DSL.

name: Bazel
description: Bazel is a build/test tool similar to Make/Maven/Gradle.

name: Earthly
description: Earthly is a syntax for defining your build leading to repeatable and understable builds.

name: Feature Flagging vendors (Launch Darkly?)
description: If your usage of feature flagging becomes sufficiently complicated then it's time to investigate third-party vendors.

name: Virtualbox based Vagrant boxes
description: Use Docker instead where possible. UI and manual testing may still use Virtualbox.

name: Flux 2
description: Flux is an implementation of GitOps for Kuberenetes

name: Redgate Platform
description: All new applications should be built on the Redgate Platform.

name: Kubernetes
description: K8S is the undeniable winner of orchestration tools.

name: SQL Server as backing store
description: When a product needs to store more complex data than it can fit in a flat file, we ask the customer for a SQL DB.

name: PostgreSQL as backing store
description: If there's a very good reason to use a lightweight/free database engine, we should choose Postgres.

name: Windows
description: Windows must be one of our supported target platforms.

name: Linux x64 (.NET supported versions)
description: Linux must be one of our supported target platforms.

name: macOS
description: MacOS must be one of our supported target platforms.

name: Virtual Machines
description: Prefer using lightweight Docker containers.

name: CLIs
description: Product should, where possible, expose funtionality via a CLI.

name: RESTful APIs
description: A REST architetural style is our default choice for building web APIs. Deviations can be made when it makes sense to do so.

name: Containerised products
description: Where possible, all new products should be built to be containerised. We should ship the Mac/Linux versions of our products inside Docker containers.

name: Infrastructure as code
description: Infrastructure should be provisioned through code rather than manually (except for ad-hoc testing)

name: Automated code style settings
description: Codebases should be formatted consistently. Automated code-style settings achieve this without fuss.

name: Static code analysis (linters)
description: Static code analysis is invaluable for automatically checking for problems in code. We use ESLint for JS and Roslyn-based analyzers for .NET. We also experimented with SonarQube but our implementation wasn't giving us confidence.

name: Semantic Versioning
description: We should use semver for all our versioning needs unless there's a compelling reason not to.

name: Database Agnosticism
description: We aim for feature parity between products that support different database engines.

name: Feature Flags
description: Feature Flags are a great technique for minimizing long-lived feature branches. Our recommendation is to focus on simplicity - if you find yourself writing substantial code to support Feature Flags, consider using a third-party solution.

name: Continuous delivery
description: Products should be ready for release at any time.

name: Continuous Deployment
description: We'd like to evaluate technology that increases our deployment frequency, with a view to getting value into the hands of our users as quickly as possible.

name: Build inside Docker containers
description: We should reduce build dependencies by building and testing our products inside containers.

name: AI/ML
description: AI/ML are becoming commoditized. Off-the-shelf software is available for predictive modelling, text analysis, anomaly detection and much more.

name: Automation/Low-code solutions
description: Remote is driving a digital transformation across industries. Low-code solutions, such as Power Apps, allow organizations to modernize these processes.

name: Git Ops
description: The core idea of GitOps is having a Git repository that always contains declarative descriptions of the infrastructure currently desired in the production environment and an automated process to make the production environment match the described state in the repository. If you want to deploy a new application or update an existing one, you only need to update the repository - the automated process handles everything else. It’s like having cruise control for managing your applications in production. Read more
